Graphical abstract The structure of a cobalt-boron catalyst obtained by reduction of cobalt chloride in an aqueous solution of sodium borohydride at ambient temperature has been investigated by TEM HR, XPS, EXAFS and X-ray diffraction method. It was found that nanoparticles of the forming catalyst consisted of a core and a shell. The oxygen-containing compounds (cobalt hydroxide and cobalt borates) mainly reside in the shell. In spite of the amorphous state of the catalyst the EXAFS and X-ray diffraction analysis indicated the presence of ferromagnetic clusters with the shortest CoCo distance of about 2.5Å and coordination number of 2.7 which are regularly distributed within the core with average separations of 5.8Å. The presence in the catalyst of the CoB bonds, a short CoCo distance and the absence of long CoCo distances (4.3 and 4.8Å) as well as the presence of boron bound to hydrogen allows suggestion to be made that stabilization of the cobalt tetramers occurs due to the presence of a boron-hydrogen structure formed by BH4 − ions upon the reduction of cobalt chloride. To substantiate the above model of the active phase of the cobalt-boron catalyst the DFT method with a PBE functional in the plane-wave basis has been employed which showed that the ferromagnetic tetramers may exist within a boron-hydrogen matrix isolated from the surrounding medium by an oxygen-containing shell. Keywords Hydrolysis Sodium borohydride Solution Cobalt catalyst Reduction 1 Introduction Amorphous cobalt borides are promising catalysts for NaBH4 and NH3BH3 hydrolysis [1–3], electrochemical water splitting [4,5] and photocathodes for hydrogen production from water [6]. They show high catalytic activity and are cost-effective as compared with platinum group metals. These materials are obtained by reduction of compounds of cobalt in an aqueous solution of sodium borohydride at room temperature. The formation rate of the active phase depends on the nature of the compounds of cobalt used. Water-soluble salts get reduced quickly and start catalyzing the process of hydride decomposition [7,8]. In the case of insoluble compounds, for example oxides, the active phase forms during several minutes [9–12]. According to the results of investigations by magnetic methods and X-ray diffraction analysis the catalytically active phase consists of amorphous particles with distinct ferromagnetic properties [13–17]. According to the recent studies they contain cobalt, boron, oxygen and hydrogen [18]. The catalytic activity of amorphous cobalt borides in sodium borohydride hydrolysis was shown to be sensitive to the content of boron [19,20]. Thus, lower contents of boron lead to a decreased activity and enhanced magnetic properties because of the formation of metallic cobalt [21,22]. This effect was especially pronounced in an alkaline medium in long-term tests of amorphous cobalt borides [23]. It should be noted that cobalt nanopowder was little active in sodium borohydride hydrolysis [24]. In 2016 the important role of boron for the activity of cobalt catalysts in sodium borohydride hydrolysis was first proved directly [25]. It was found that addition of boron to catalysts prepared by magnetron sputtering of cobalt onto a Ni foil led to a higher rate of sodium borohydride hydrolysis per cobalt atom than was possible with an analogously prepared cobalt catalyst [26]. And the more boron was present in the catalyst the higher was its activity. It was suggested that this effect was due to the increased dispersion of the metallic phase. Replacement of boron by carbon in the magnetron sputtering synthesis resulted in a twofold drop in the rate of NaBH4 hydrolysis in spite of similar textural characteristic of cobalt-boron and cobalt-carbon catalysts. However, during 7 test cycles of the cobalt-carbon catalyst there was a growth in activity. An XPS study of the CoC catalyst before and after the reaction revealed appearance and accumulation of boron in the catalyst sample. Thus, the in situ formation of a CoB phase on the surface of cobalt-carbon catalysts may be considered to be the main reason for their increased activity in sodium borohydride hydrolysis. In spite of the growing number of publications [27,28] on cobalt-boron catalysts reduced in a medium of sodium borohydride, no single opinion has been reached so far as to the structure of the CoB phase since most of the studied catalysts were heat-treated above 200°C [29–31]. No attention has been given to the fact that the value of the residual magnetization of the CoB phase was smaller than in metallic cobalt and cobalt borides. The aim of the present work was to get an insight into the structure of not heat-treated cobalt-boron catalyst prepared by reduction of cobalt chloride in an aqueous solution of sodium borohydride at room temperature. On the basis of the results obtained by TEM HR, XPS, EXAFS and X-ray diffraction method a possible structure of the CoB phase was proposed and substantiated by quantum chemical methods. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Commercial chemical reagents: sodium borohydride, NaBH4 (Acros Organics, 98wt%) and cobalt (II) chloride hexahydrate, CoCl2·6H2O (GOST 4525-77) were used as received. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Cobalt-boron catalyst was prepared by reduction of cobalt chloride in an aqueous solution of sodium borohydride (0.12M) at ambient temperature and a molar ratio of Co:NaBH4 =1:25. The reduced catalyst was extracted from the reaction medium, washed with distilled water and acetone and dried at 60°С in a vacuum drying box for 4h. The catalyst was stored in a desiccator under argon. The cobalt-boron catalysts are denoted as CoB. 2.3 Hydrogen generation experiments Sodium borohydride hydrolysis was carried out at 40°C in a temperature-controlled glass reactor with a magnetic stirrer at 800rpm. At stirring rates higher than 200rpm the influence of the external diffusion processes was found to be negligible [32]. 10mL of an aqueous solution of sodium borohydride was loaded into the reactor. A weighed amount of the cobalt catalyst (0.0117g) was then added and the volume of the released hydrogen gas was measured with a gas burette. For data reliability each experiment was repeated at least three times. The experimental values from different runs differed within ±1%. 2.4 Catalyst characterization The chemical analysis (contents of cobalt and boron) was performed by atomic-emission spectroscopy with inductively-coupled plasma on an Optima 4300 DV instrument (Germany). The magnetic characterization was performed using a vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM-7407, Lake Shore) in Ar atmosphere. The hysteresis loop was recorded in an applied magnetic field between −5kOe and +5kOe. The high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR TEM) studies were performed on a (JEM-2010, Japan) instrument with a lattice resolution of 1.4Ǻ and an accelerating voltage of 200kV. The elemental analysis was carried out by energy dispersive X-ray microanalysis (EDX) on an EDAX Phoenix spectrometer equipped with a Si(Li) detector with an energy resolution of 130eV and higher. The samples to be analyzed were mounted on a holey carbon film which was attached to a standard copper grid. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were recorded on a SPECS (Germany) photoelectron spectrometer using a hemispherical PHOIBOS-150-MCD-9 analyzer and FOCUS-500 (AlKα radiation, hv =1486.74eV, 150W) monochromator. The binding energy (BE) scale was pre-calibrated using the positions of the peaks of Au4f7/2 (BE=84.0eV) and Cu2p3/2 (BE=932.67eV) core levels. The samples were placed onto a conducting double-sided copper scotch. The C 1s peak at 284.8eV was used as the internal standard to remove the effect of recharging process appearing in the course of electron photoemission. The survey spectra were taken at analyzer pass energy of 50eV and the detailed spectra (B 1s, C 1s, O 1s Co 2p) were registered at 20eV. Analysis of the individual spectral regions allowed determination of peaks, identification of the chemical state of elements and calculation of atomic concentration ratios of elements on the sample surface, which were corrected using corresponding atomic sensitivity factor [33]. The ion bombardment of the sample was performed using an argon ion gun (SPECS model IQE 11/35). The energy of Ar+ ions, the current density and the beam angle were 2.5keV, 7–8μA/cm2, and 45°, respectively. The depth profiling rate under these conditions was estimated as ∼0.3nm/min [34]. Bombardment of the sample by argon ions during 10min allowed removal of a surface layer with a thickness of at least 3nm. The EXAFS spectra of the K absorption edge of cobalt were recorded using the standard procedure [35] at the EXAFS Station of the Siberian Synchrotron and Terahertz Radiation Centre (Novosibirsk, Russia) on a VEPP-3 storage ring with an electron energy of 2GeV and an average current of 80mA. A silicon crystal cleaved along the (111) plane was used as the monochromator. The EXAFS spectra were taken in the transmittance mode and fluorescence registration using proportional chambers and a photomultiplier as detectors. The energy step of the spectra was 2.0eV. The sample cell thickness was chosen so as to achieve an absorption jump of Δμx 0.8 on the L3 edge of cobalt. For all samples, the χ(k) oscillations of the EXAFS spectrum were analyzed as k2χ(k) in the wave number range k=2.5–12.0Å−1. To process the oscillations of the absorption curve and to model the spectra VIPER software was used [36]. The scattering parameters were obtained using the FEFF 7 package [37]. To determine the chemical nature of the scattering atoms in the vicinity of the absorbing atom [38], a cobalt foil (CAS 7440-48-4), Co3O4 (CAS 1308-06-1), CoO (CAS 1307-96-6), crystalline Co2B prepared from amorphous Co65B35 sample [39] were used as model compounds. X-Ray diffraction patterns (CuKα) for polycrystalline Co and СoB catalyst were obtained under identical instrument conditions with the DRON-UM1 diffractometer. The value of q is calculated using the formula q=2πsinθ/λ. 2.5 Structure calculations of the cobalt-boron catalyst The calculations of different structures have been performed using the DFT method with a PBE functional in a plane wave basis (the upper limit of the kinetic energy 40Ry). The electronic states of the core shells were approximated by the pseudo-potential method [40]. The Quantum-Espresso 5.02 software package was used [41], the calculations were performed on a supercomputer of the Siberian Branch of the Russian Academy of Sciences. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical properties of CoB catalysts obtained by reduction of cobalt chloride in a solution of sodium borohydride The addition of cobalt chloride to a solution of sodium borohydride leads to instantaneous formation of a black ferromagnetic (Fig. 1 ) solid which starts to catalyze hydrolysis of this hydride. But the amount of hydrogen evolved as a result of cobalt chloride reduction never exceeded 93% of the theoretical yield According to the chemical analysis the СoB catalyst contains 75.9wt.% of the metal and 6.3wt.% of boron. The cobalt-to-boron mole ratio is about 2, a typical value for catalysts prepared by reduction of cobalt chloride by sodium borohydride [42–45]. It should be noted that the total content of Со and В is less than 100 % because of the presence oxygen and hydrogen with small amounts of sodium and chlorine. In an earlier study the molar ratio of the elements in such cobalt-boron catalysts was found to be Co:B:O:H=3.2:1.5:1.4:1 [18]. As shown in Fig. 3 the CoB was forming as spherical particles surrounded by a 3–5nm thick shell. According to an EDX analysis (Fig. 3c), oxygen mainly resides in the shell in the form of oxygen-containing compounds: cobalt hydroxide or cobalt borate [46,47]. After reduction, the CoB catalyst was studied by XPS (Fig. 4 ). The Co2p spectra show the binding energy peaks of Co (2p3/2) and Co (2p1/2) of ∼781 and ∼795eV, respectively [48]. Analysis of the electronic state of cobalt was performed for the Co2p3/2 region. It can unambiguously be said that in the studied samples the value of the binding energy of the Co2p3/2 peak of 781.2eV is characteristic of cobalt in the Co2+ state. This state is characterized by the presence of a strong satellite shifted from the main Co2p3/2 peak by about 5.6eV towards higher binding energies [49]. Here it should be noted that for the studied CoB catalyst the charge state of Co3+ is not typical because characteristic of Co3+ is the value of the binding energy of the Co2p3/2 peak of 779.9eV as well as the presence of a small satellite shifted from the main Co2p3/2 peak by about 9.5eV towards higher binding energies [50,51]. The spectrum of Co2p3/2 (Fig. 5 a) shows two peaks at 778.2 and 781.2eV. The value of the binding energy of the first peak is characteristic of metallic cobalt (Co0). Corresponding to the binding energy of the second peak is cobalt hydroxide [52] or cobalt borate [53]. It should be noted that cobalt borate is characterized by a greater covalence of the CoO bond than it in cobalt hydroxide [54,55]. From the B1s spectrum (Fig. 5b) it is seen that boron, too, is present in two states. The binding energy of the second peak 191.8eV coincides with the value characteristic of B3+ in borates [1,56]. The binding energy of the first peak 188.0eV cannot be unambiguously assigned to elemental boron (B0) in amorphous state (187.5eV) [57]. The smaller electronic density on boron in metal-boron alloys (CoB, Co2B, Ni3B, Fe2B, FeB, Mn2B) was usually explained by sp-states of boron strongly hybridizing with the metal d-states [58]. However, this conclusion is only valid for cobalt borides with a crystalline structure [59] or clusters of amorphous CoB alloys (consisting of 1500 atoms) whose CoCo distances have coordination numbers exceeding 10 and where the boron atoms have no contacts to each other [60]. The performed calculations [59,60] show that increase in boron content to 2 atoms per one cobalt atom must lead to a significant fall of the magnetic moment so that the ferromagnetism of Co2B becomes unstable. In our case, the amorphous cobalt-boron catalyst obtained by reduction of cobalt chloride in aqueous solution of sodium borohydride at ambient temperature shows strong magnetic properties (Fig. 1). Taking into account that the СoB catalyst contains not only cobalt and boron but also a considerable amount of hydrogen (Co:B:O:H=3.2:1.5:1.4:1), the obtained value of the binding energy (188.0eV) was compared with the B1s level binding energies in compounds of the type Men(BHx)m. Characteristic of these compounds is the binding energy of 187.9±0,2eV [61,62] which coincides with our result. The evolution of hydrogen from the СoB catalyst at 230°С [18] gives an additional proof of the presence of boron-hydrogen fragments. According to the literature [63] decomposing in this temperature interval are higher borohydrides. Analysis of the B1s and Co2p2/3 spectra indicated the presence of oxygen bound to boron and cobalt. The presence in the sample of several non-equivalent states of oxygen atoms is also indicated by the asymmetry of the broad (>2eV) peak of O1s. Its deconvolution gives two states of oxygen with binding energies 531.6 and 533.0eV (Fig. 5c). Whereas the first binding energy coincides with the value characteristic of CoO type of bonding in Co(OH)2 [64], the second value corresponds to the BO type of bonding in borates [65]. After removal of the oxygen-containing shell by bombardment by argon ions there were changes in the XPS spectra of the sample. The intensity of the peak in the O1s spectrum (Fig. 5c) was decreased substantially and its maximum was shifted by 0.4eV towards higher energies. A similar shift of the maximum corresponding to B3+ was observed in the B1s spectrum (Fig. 5b) but the binding energy of B0 remained unchanged. It is known that the energies of the O1s and B1s levels in oxygen-containing compounds are rather sensitive to the structure of the nearest environment of oxygen and boron atoms [66,67]. Deconvolution of the O1s peak into two components with binding energies 531.6 and 533.0eV shows that the ratio «BO/CoO» increases from 0.25 to 0.7 on going from the shell to the core (Table 1 ). Considering the substantially smaller content of oxygen in the core as compared with the shell and the practically uniform distribution of B3+ throughout the particle volume it can be concluded that most of the cobalt in the core exists in a reduced state. This also follows from the increased intensity of the peak with the binding energy 778.2eV in the spectrum of Co2p3/2 (Fig. 5a). As mentioned above, after removal of the shell changes in the intensity of the B1s spectrum were insignificant (Fig. 5b). But the lines of the spectrum were broadened and their deconvolution gave four components with the binding energies 188.0, 189.3, 191.8 and 192.9eV. According to the literature, the 188.0eV peak is attributable to compounds of the type Men(BHx)m [61], the peak 191.8eV to cobalt borate [56] and the peak 192.9eV to B2O3 or orthoboric acid H3BO3 but the origin of the 189.3eV has not been clarified yet. It was proposed [57] that this peak could be attributed to the B atoms bound to chlorine and metal atoms, for example as in Na2B10C10·xH2O compound. From the survey spectrum (Fig. 4) it is seen that the sample with the removed shell has small contents of sodium and chlorine. Thus, the addition of cobalt chloride to a solution of sodium borohydride leads to the formation of spherical particles of ferromagnetic active catalytic phase consisting of a core and a shell. The main component of the core is reduced cobalt with some admixtures of cobalt borates, compounds containing sodium, chlorine and boron-hydrogen fragments. They are isolated from the surrounding medium by an oxygen-containing shell (Fig. 3b), which apparently forms as a result of oxidation of the active component in the course of the reaction or after the complete conversion of the hydride in the alkaline solution with рН=13.6 (Fig. 6 ) [32]. 3.2 A study of the structure of CoB catalyst obtained by reduction of cobalt chloride in solution of sodium borohydride Since the oxygen-containing shell amounts only to 3–5nm, EXAFS method may by used to obtain information about the local environment of cobalt in the core of in-situ reduced CoB catalysts, Fig. 7 shows an ARDF curve of a wet CoB sample reduced by NaBH4 immediately before the measurement. From an analysis of this curve it can be concluded that the first coordination sphere of cobalt is described by a set of CoCo and CoB distances. Similar ARDF curves were observed earlier for amorphous СоВ catalysts [68–70]. The short distance 2.05Å with the coordination number 1.6 can be attributed to СоВ and the distance 2.46Å with the coordination number 2.7, to СоСо. The obtained value of the СоСо distance coincides with the value of the СоСо distance typical of metallic cobalt (2.48Å) with a hexagonal structure whereas in stoichiometric cobalt borides this distance is greater [71,72]. According to the obtained results (Fig. 7) the ARDF curves shows no СоСо distances in the distant coordination shells characteristic of stoichiometric boride Co2B [73] or metallic cobalt [74], probably because of the greater disorder in the structure of СоВ catalyst. According to EXAFS (Fig. 7) there takes place the structure transformation of СоВ catalyst after the washing with acetone and drying at 60°С under vacuum. The ARDF curve for this sample (Fig. 7) shows a СоСо distance (2.47Å) with the coordination number 3.3 and a СоВ distance (2,08Å) with the coordination number 2.7. The interatomic distances did not change strongly in the course of the drying but the coordination numbers were increasing both for the СоСо and СоВ (Table 2 ) which may be caused by removal of water from the sample and an ordering of the cobalt tetramers coordinated by boron. It is noted that cobalt clusters are stable even at 300°С, because for the СоСо distance the coordination number does not exceed 4 [18]. The EXAFS analysis has been supplemented by an X-ray investigation which gave a more informative picture. Fig. 8 demonstrates X-Ray diffraction patterns for crystalline Co and СoB catalyst. It is seen that the Bragg scattering (characteristic of the crystal state) is absent in catalyst. There is only an intense diffuse main maximum at q =3.16Å−1 and a weaker maximum at 5.30Å−1. To the left from the main maximum there are weakly pronounced additional maxima at q =1.33 and 2.44Å−1 (so-called pre-peaks). The atomic form factors are known to be proportional to the element number (Z) in the Periodic Table Since Z=27 for Co and Z=5 for B it is clear that the diffraction pattern in СoB catalyst mainly depends on the space location of cobalt atoms and hence a comparison of the patterns for Co and catalyst is reasonable. At room temperature Co has a hexagonal structure (space group P 63/mmc with lattice parameters a = b =2.5059Å, c =4.0709Å). The Bragg peaks for polycrystalline cobalt (99.3% Со) in Fig. 8a coincide with these parameters. With the appearance in the diffraction patterns of features indicating the amorphous state of the sample, there arises the question of whether the substance under study is truly amorphous or the observed diffraction patterns are a result of a small size of the crystallites. The latter state is sometimes called X-ray amorphous. To elucidate this situation, X-ray diffraction patterns for polycrystalline cobalt with different sizes of crystallites (L) (Fig. 9 ) have been calculated using the well-known program «Fullprof» [75]. It is seen that as the crystallite size becomes smaller the Bragg peaks are markedly broadened and blurred and at L ≤20Å the diffraction patterns become rather close to those observed in СoB catalyst. Therefore we made an attempt to more correctly describe this diffraction pattern within a microcrystalline model by taking into account not only the crystallite size but also the Debye–Waller factor as variables. In the calculations, the results of which are shown in Fig. 9, the crystallites were taken to be ideal (with no defects) for all crystallite sizes. Actually, however, in small crystallites there always tend to be damages in their near-surface layers during the process of their preparation. With the decreasing size of the crystallites the fraction of the damaged volume in them will increase substantially. The arising defects inevitably lead to static non-correlated displacements of atoms from their ideal positions. The well-known parameter B in the Debye-Waller factor determined from the experiment characterizes both average statistical thermal and static mean-square uncorrelated displacements of atoms <u 2>. Using the relation В =8π2 <u 2> it is possible to calculate <u 2> from experimental data [76]. Fig. 10 shows the results of the most successful application of the above micro-crystallite model to describe the experiment (L =12Å; <u 2>1/2 =0.28Å give fitting quality parameters R b =8.6% and χ=5.8). It is interesting to note that the best fitting value <u 2>1/2 =0.28Å was exactly equal to the boundary value between the crystalline and amorphous states within the distortion model of amorphization [77]. From Fig. 10 it is seen that our calculations give a rather adequate description of both the location and form of the main maximum (with the exception of the pre-peak) at reasonably small changes of the lattice parameters but absolutely fails to describe the next diffuse maximum. It is a strong argument in favor of the conclusion that observed diffraction pattern cannot be described by the micro-crystallite model. Meanwhile, the positions of the experimental peaks may be given a within the formalism adopted for the description of truly amorphous solids. It is known [78], that the location of diffuse maxima on the diffraction pattern for an amorphous solid is determined as a sequence of maxima of the function sin(qr)/qr, i.e. as the roots of equation tg(qr 1)= qr 1, which are equal to 7.73; 14.06; 20.46, and etc. Therefore from the diffraction pattern it is possible to estimate the shortest interatomic distance r 1. In our case, starting from the location of the main and the subsequent peaks we obtain: r 1 =7.73/3.16≈14.06/5.30 or <r 1>≈2.5Å. Remember that the shortest distance between Co atoms in the crystalline state is equal to 2.5059Å. It is in agreement with the statement [78] that the shortest interatomic distances do not change substantially upon amorphization. Therefore, such an analysis shows that СoB catalyst under study is truly amorphous. When an amorphous solid has a more complex structure than a random close packing of solid spheres, for example, when it is formed by coordination polyhedrons or atomic-scale clusters, then along with the interatomic interference there also should be an interpolyhedral interference. The pre-peaks in our case may be due to the existence of such formations within an amorphous matrix. Then they correspond to r 2 =7.73/1.33≈14.06/2.44 or <r 2>≈5.8Å. Fig. 11 shows the so-called normalized scattering structure function S(q) obtained from the X-ray data in Fig. 10. It is seen that the pre-peak at q =1.33Å−1 appears there more distinctly. Thus, the X-ray diffraction data confirm that СoB catalyst is a truly amorphous sample containing clusters with the nearest СоСо distance equal to 2.5Å which is in agreement with the EXAFS data. The clusters within the amorphous matrix lie rather regularly at an average distance of 5.8Å. 3.3 A quantum-chemical modeling of clusters of the active phase of CoB catalyst forming in a medium of sodium borohydride Summing up the results of magnetic susceptibility, XPS, EXAFS and X-Ray diffraction studies it can be concluded that the studied sample of СoB catalyst contains ferromagnetic tetramers of cobalt with a typical СоСо distance of 2.46Å and a coordination number of 2.7. The Co–Co distances in the distant coordination shells are absent which was not the case with the crystalline boride Со2В [73] and metallic cobalt. The question arises what are the reasons for the existence of cobalt clusters since a substantial energy is required to stabilize them (to 377kJ/mol). It should be noted that the cobalt atoms are coordinated by boron which may enter into the composition of boron-hydrogen fragments, according to XPS data: in the B1s spectrum the binding energy of 188.0eV corresponds to compounds of the type Men(BHx)m. Taking into account the presence of oxidized boron in the volume of the sample it can be suggested that a portion of boron bound to cobalt may contain oxygen in its first coordination sphere. It is known from the literature [79] that polyborane [B12H12]2− ions are stable in water even when hydrogen was replaced by a hydroxyl group [B12H11OH]2− or [B12H10(OH)2]2−. Considering the regular arrangement of cobalt clusters in the amorphous matrix for which the X-ray analysis indicated separations of 5.8Å, it can be suggested that the clusters have a boron-hydrogen environment of BH4 − ions coming from the aqueous solution. Formation of various metalloboranes was observed in the decomposition of metal borohydride (e.g. LiBH4) [79]. These intermediate compounds are stable in water. When modeling the structure of СoB catalysts it was taken into account that higher metal borohydrides represent molecular sieves [80–82] with cavities large enough to accommodate small metallic clusters. Considering this key factor, the structure of B8H12 (Fig. 12 ) was used as the starting structure in the modeling since it allows stabilization of small clusters of cobalt by the remaining [B8H10]* fragments. Experimentally measured molar B:H ratio is close to that of B8H12 [83] when the amount of hydrogen was referred only to the amount of the reduced form of boron. Moreover, the average separation between the B8H12 fragments is about 6 Å in crystal cell (Fig. 12). It can therefore be suggested that Co4 clusters may lie inside the tetrahedron formed by the nearest B8H12 molecules (Fig. 12). A DFT simulation cell was built based on the X-Ray structure of B8H12 (ICSD #43256). The cell parameters and atomic positions were optimized for the lowest enthalpy. The optimum structure of a cobalt cluster with typical interatomic distances is shown in Fig. 13 . On the average, the СоСо distances inside the cavities of the boron-hydrogen matrix vary from 2.19 to 2.53Å within a cluster. According to the calculations, these cobalt-boron clusters are ferromagnetic. Thus, the model allows us to explain the presence of the CoB distance and one short СоСо distance with the coordination number 2.7 in the EXAFS spectrum (Fig. 7) and to agree with the X-ray diffraction data (Fig. 11) about the regular arrangement of the cobalt clusters in the amorphous boron-hydrogen matrix. 4 Conclusions Using HR TEM, XPS, EXAFS and X-ray diffraction method a cobalt-boron catalyst for sodium borohydride hydrolysis has been investigated. It was shown that the active phase forming from the cobalt chloride as a result of reduction by sodium borohydride solution consists of nanosized particles with an amorphous core and sn oxygen-containing shell. The molar ratio of the elements in the sample was Co:B:O:H=3.2:1.5:1.4:1. It was shown by XPS was that the core contained reduced cobalt and some compounds of boron (cobalt borates, boron oxide), compounds containing sodium and chlorine as well as boron-hydrogen fragments. The core is isolated from the surrounding medium by an oxygen-containing shell, which ensures stability of the compounds inside the core. In spite of the amorphous state of the CoB catalyst, EXAFS and X-ray diffraction investigations have shown that the catalyst contained ferromagnetic clusters of cobalt with the nearest СоСо distance of about 2.5Å and CoB distance of about 2.05Å. Drying the sample at 60°С under vacuum led to an increase in coordination number from 2.7 to 3.3 for СоСо and from 1.6 to 2.7 for CoB with only inconsiderable changes in the interatomic distances. This appears to be a result of removal of water from the sample and an ordering of the cobalt tetramers coordinated by boron. These tetramers have a regular distribution and are separated from each other by an average distance of 5.8Å. A quantum-chemical modeling of the clusters of the active phase in the studied CoB catalyst forming in a NaBH4 solution has been performed for the first time. A model has been proposed on the basis of the B8H12 structure which suggests stabilization of the ferromagnetic tetramers of cobalt in the cavities of a boron-hydrogen matrix. The model allows an explanation of the presence of CoB bonds and one short СоСо distance in the ARDF curve with no long СоСо distances. Taking into account the regular arrangement of cobalt clusters within the amorphous matrix as followed from analysis of X-ray diffraction data, it can be suggested that after their formation in the NaBH4 solution the cobalt tetramers take part in the growth of a boron-hydride matrix from the BH4 − coming from the solution. The following three observations give an additional support of this hypothesis: (I) reduction of cobalt chloride always evolves less hydrogen than its amount predicted by the theory (Fig. 2); (II) the content of hydrogen in the sample is 0.46wt%; (III) hydrogen evolution takes place at 230°С, the temperature of the decomposition of higher boron hydrides [63,84]. coredata.dc:description: The structure of a cobalt-boron catalyst obtained by reduction of cobalt chloride in an aqueous solution of sodium borohydride at ambient temperature has been investigated by TEM HR, XPS, EXAFS and X-ray diffraction method. It was found that nanoparticles of the forming catalyst consisted of a core and a shell. The oxygen-containing compounds (cobalt hydroxide and cobalt borates) mainly reside in the shell. In spite of the amorphous state of the catalyst the EXAFS and X-ray diffraction analysis indicated the presence of ferromagnetic clusters with the shortest CoCo distance of about 2.5Å and coordination number of 2.7 which are regularly distributed within the core with average separations of 5.8Å. The presence in the catalyst of the CoB bonds, a short CoCo distance and the absence of long CoCo distances (4.3 and 4.8Å) as well as the presence of boron bound to hydrogen allows suggestion to be made that stabilization of the cobalt tetramers occurs due to the presence of a boron-hydrogen structure formed by BH4 − ions upon the reduction of cobalt chloride. To substantiate the above model of the active phase of the cobalt-boron catalyst the DFT method with a PBE functional in the plane-wave basis has been employed which showed that the ferromagnetic tetramers may exist within a boron-hydrogen matrix isolated from the surrounding medium by an oxygen-containing shell.
coredata.dc:title: Cobalt-boron catalyst for NaBH4 hydrolysis: The state of the active component forming from cobalt chloride in a reaction medium
